title: I would rather have doubled or trippled queue time than playing with autofills!
body:
Some Rioter wrote a couple days ago that they cant abandon autofill without double or tripple queue time.
I would say: ok.... DO IT!

90% of my lostgames are because of autofills!

replies.body: Auto fills are the spice of life though. They are the wild card and make things unpredictable

No it's not, as long as the guy has half a brain and aknowledge he should play a passive lane on a champion who can clean easily.

Now when the support main starts playing Cassio top, you shouldnt expect anything good, but it has nothing to do with being autofilled, it's just a lack of basic logic.

It's not a lack of basic logic, it's a lack of understanding the ins and outs of a certain role. Someone who mains top lane will understand exactly when their champion is strong, when the enemy champion is strong, when the enemy jungler in near them and play safe etc whilst someone autofilled won't know any of that and are reduced to hoping their team can carry them.

Nope. You dont need to understand your role in order to not feed, not get caugh and not garantee a loss for your team. Yes you are unlikely to carry, but you dont need to carry. Not being a dead weight the rare times you are autofill is enough.

Unless you get autofilled to support/adc and get hooked by Thresh/Pyke/Blitzcrank or all ined by a Leona or Alistar. Or you get autofilled jungle and are getting perma invaded by a Xin Zhao/Graves/Kindred. Or you get autofilled top and are against someone such as Pantheon who jump on you every time you try to get any cs.

Then you play sivir or cait and just clear. (or you play Morgana supp)
If you are toplane you play a ranged safe champion and you play the farm game as well. (IE Malzar top)

The only difficulty is to be humble enough to recognize that, being autofilled, you will not shine, you will not carry, but at least you can help your team and not be a dead weight.

If that was how Riot intended for you to play auto fill,  then it'd be a reportable offense if someone first timed Riven and went 2/11/3 (it isn't). 

Regardless, a good player has the potential to annihilate someone autofilled to a lane they aren't familiar with no matter what champion they play.

> Regardless, a good player has the potential to annihilate someone autofilled to a lane they aren't familiar with no matter what champion they play.

x Doubt. If you face a good player (which only happens when you are in the top 0.1%), you are also good enough to hold a lane. 

If you are not in the top 0.1% you can't face good players since you are not one yourself.

Also, most of the time while autofilled i still pick my main champion, plays a bit safer and it's fine. Since now most champions are also viable botlane....

Trying to debunk my argument based on what qualifies as a 'good' player is irrelevant. To an Iron player a Gold player is good and to a Gold player a Diamond player is good etc. 

Most players have certain roles that they completely avoid like the plague and this argument is being made for when these players get auto filled, not when people who play an even split of each role who willingly select the fill option in lobby. 

Simply put, League is a mechanical game. Each role has slight intricacies that differentiate it from the next, most notably, the champions that you'll generally be facing. Someone who has mained top lane for years will know exactly which champions do what and when they're at their strongest. Whether their enemy has a super powerful early game and which have a powerful late game and as a result need to be punished during the early game. This is a simple concept that even an auto-filled player should know. They then might be put against someone like a Fiora or Tryndamere and think that they have excellent late game and so they need to fight them early to prevent them from becoming such monsters, only for them to learn the hard way that they are very capable of fighting and winning early game under certain stipulations. 

The reverse is also true. They may sit so far away from a Pantheon that they are unable to get any CS and Pantheon becomes huge just based on his CS lead. These sorts of arguments can be made with every single role in the game.

You are taking extreme cases and turn it into generalities.

I'm not a genius,  but when I pay attention i'm very capable of at least not feeding and still getting enough CS to stay revelant in the game in any role.

Not automatically by playing the role as it's supposed to be played, when i'm autofilled ADC I will play a mage because I KNOW i do not have the mecanics. When playing support vs a hard lane you might take Morgana to be extra safe, but you can also play a mage as well. 

People who "can't autofill" are both lazy and not imaginative.

I as many people ruining game while being in their main role as I see autofilled people ruining in their offrole.

Back in previous seasons (5 and before) pick order ruled and people played every single role.

These aren't extreme cases. This sort of thing often happens when dealing with an autofilled player. Not feeding does not equate to doing well. Say you pick a mage bot lane and the enemy picks a tank, suddenly you're left with no way to deal with said tank once they get a few items. 

At the end of the day playing League of Legends is about having fun and playing under tower to avoid feeding isn't fun. Playing with someone who's autofilled also isn't fun.

The fact that people do not queue up for all roles evenly will bottleneck any queue system by the least played role. It doesn't take long before queue times get out of control if you don't auto fill people.

Assume you have 100 people who queue and 15% of people queue top. then you have 25 people stuck queueing. 5 minutes later another 100 people join queue and 15% of those 100 play top. You will have 50 people stuck queueing after that point.

Now I don't have the data on riot's queue system and what % of people are queueing up each role but the fact that they are auto filling at all means there is a bottleneck and queue times can increase indefinitely.

Riot should make two systems then, one option is matchmaking without auto fill and the other is with auto fill.

That way high elo, or those that want it, have auto fill to make their queue time faster. But there is another system/option for those that don’t want autofill, and doesn’t mind longer queue times.

This could be an option in the game mode selection screen or a button that you have to press when in the lobby

Riot already tried something like this internally. What happens, is that this creates a snowball effect, allowing people to choose whether or not to enable autofill. Let's say that 50% of people choose to disable autofill. The 50% of people who didn't, are now autofilling more often to make up for the folk who have disabled it, resulting in more people being autofilled. With people getting autofilled more constantly, people get sick of it, and choose to disable autofill.

This leads the people who didn't disable getting autofilled even more often, and then they start rarely getting the roles they want to play, which leads to them disabling it, rinse, repeat, rinse, repeat. Autofill may be a burden for a few folk, but it needs to be a shared burden, so that the effect is minimal for the player.

I think auto fill should only apply to Diamond + elo. At that level you should be experienced enough to be somewhat competent in any role. Low elo is where auto fill really screws people over, and the low elo player base is large enough for queue times to not be that bad.

yes that's the point.
And you ask a doctor what an ekg stands for, and they might know. And tell you.
You ask a top laner about wave control on mid lane, and they might now.

You ask a top laner to play support, you're fucked. Likewise for support to top. Or worse, jungle.
However, just because you ask a doctor what an ekg means, doesn't mean you should expect an actual answer.

Like, I'm a software developer, but i don't know the definitions to most things, so if I'm asked about "gimme the definition of static", "tell me the characteristics of classes", "what does encapsulation mean", I got no flipping clue.
But when something has to be done, and i understand what has to be done. I can implement it and make it happen in a pretty efficient manner.

That's the thing about specialization.
And this is what happens in Lol. To a large degree with roles and to a pretty high degrees with champions.

That's why there are so many "one tricks" (or people that play 3 or less champions) at higher elos (above gold).
Because they specialized into learning a role, learning how it works, and how to play their champion in that role. How to trade, when to roam, when to gank, when to engage, when to disengage, etc. 
And most of that is learned subconsciously, as most of us don't make it an active part of their day to get better at this game.

And that's why, back to the initial point. Someone that might be diamond or challanger in mid lane. Is most likely to suck as support.
Even if they are amazing on lets say Yasuo or Zed mid. They will most likely be much weaker on Annie for example.
While my peak was only plat, I was able to play stuff like pre rework malzahar, diana and pre rework akali on mid at a pretty high level.
But if I were put to play lets say Zed, Yasuo, Talon, Fizz, Annie, Vel'Coz, reworked Malzahar, etc. My skill level would drop to gold tier to low gold tier. And I wouldn't be able to win lane or carry games.

Because specialization is a thing.
You know how to play against X doesn't matter THAT much. Like lets say:
You play top and you are mid or support or adc main, you know darius has a grab, a slow, a heal and an armor shread. And if he attacks you to much, you will blead and his ult will do true dmg. 
What you do NOT know:
when can you trade with darius?
how many auto attacks from him can you eat before you HAVE to back out?
if he does grab you, do you flash right away, or you trade with him?
what do you build as first item, should you go defensive or offensive?
do you take tp or ignite?
can darius tower dive you?
can he freeze the wave?
what the fuck do you do when the wave is frozen?
and more.

just because "oh wow, i know how the enemy champion plays" isn't enough.
And the discrepancy of someone that knows all the little details is muuuuuuuuuuch higher and punishing at higher elos (high dia+). Because those small details make the difference between who is dying and who is surviving.
Its a game of who makes the least amount of mistakes wins.
In bronze, silver and gold people make mistakes all the time. Even in plat and dia mistakes happen at like at least several times per game. I don't know if i ever had a game where I could say "i played this perfectly, there was nothing i could've done better".
So ofc, when both of you make mistakes, then, the "gap" doesn't matter as much, as when a mistake is large enough, you can turn the tide. But the higher elo you go, the less mistakes are being done. And the harder it is to turn the tide.
And that's why, specialization pays off so hard.

Again, you don't go to ask a doctor (ie: a top laner) how to do your legal strategy in a case of money laundering and tax evasions (support).
You don't ask the ship captain (adc) how long will the surgery take and what are the odds you will survive
And you won't ask your lawyer (support) how long till you reach the land as you've been on the see for 3 days now.
